overview: Find out about National Insurance - your National Insurance Number, what it's for, how much you pay, how to check your contributions record
title: National Insurance

table.body:
You pay National Insurance contributions to build up your entitlement to certain state benefits, including the State Pension. 

You pay National Insurance if:

- you're an employee or self-employed
- and you're 16 or over, earning above £139 a week

The amount you pay depends on:

- how much you earn
- whether you're employed or self-employed

If you're employed, you stop paying National Insurance when you reach the [State Pension age.](http://pensions-service.direct.gov.uk/en/state-pension-age-calculator/home.asp "State Pension age"){:rel="external"} 

If you're self-employed:

- you stop paying Class 2 National Insurance contributions when you reach State Pension age
- you stop paying Class 4 contributions from the start of the tax year after the one in which you reach State Pension age

If you're employed you pay National Insurance via PAYE (Pay As You Earn). This is where your contributions are taken from your wages before you get paid. 

If you're self-employed you pay via [Self Assessment](/file-your-self-assessment-tax-return "Self Assessment").

If you're abroad or need to top up gaps in your National Insurance record (eg if you're not working and not eligible for [National Insurance credits](/boost-state-pension/national-insurance-credits-eligibility "National Insurance credits")), you can also pay [voluntary National Insurance contributions.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/volcontr/abroad.htm "voluntary National Insurance contributions"){:rel="external"} 

You might have to pay National Insurance [if you're working in the European Union](/work-in-another-eu-country/national-insurance "if you're working in the European Union").

^If your circumstances change, [tell HMRC (HM Revenue & Customs)](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?raction=view&fl0=__dsid%3A&sm=0&ha=34&as=1&sp_scope=hmrc&sc=hmrc&nh=10&sr=0&cs=ISO-8859-1&tx1=&tx0=49620 "tell HMRC"){:rel="external"} so they can keep your records up to date.^

*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Your National Insurance number makes sure your National Insurance and tax contributions are properly recorded. 

It's made up of letters and numbers and never changes. 

^You can apply to [get a National Insurance number](/national-insurance-number "get a National Insurance number") if you don't have one.^

##Who uses your National Insurance number

These organisations may need to know what your number is:

- HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)
- your employer
- the Department for Work and Pensions (which includes Jobcentre Plus and the Pension, Disability and Carers Service), if you claim state benefits
- your local council, if you claim Housing Benefit
- the Student Loan Company, if you apply for a student loan
- your ISA provider, if you open an ISA

^To prevent identity fraud, keep your National Insurance number safe and don't give it to anyone who doesn't need it.^

*[ISA]:Individual Savings Account

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Your National Insurance number

table.body:
##If you're employed

You pay Class 1 National Insurance contributions. The rates are:

- 12% on your weekly earnings between £139 to £817  
- an extra 2% on any earnings over £817 

##If you're self-employed

You pay Class 2 and Class 4 National Insurance contributions. The rates are:

- Class 2 - a flat rate of £2.50 a week
- Class 4 - a percentage of your annual taxable profits (9% on profits between £7,225 to £42,475, and a further 2% on profits over that amount)

There's more information on the HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) website on [tax and National Insurance if you're self-employed.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/working/intro/selfemployed.htm "tax and National Insurance if you're self-employed"){:rel="external"}

##Voluntary contributions

You can pay [voluntary National Insurance contributions](/boost-state-pension/voluntary-national-insurance-contributions "voluntary National Insurance contributions") to cover any shortfalls in your payment record. This will boost your State Pension.

^There's a full list of [National Insurance rates](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/rates/nic.htm "National Insurance rates"){:rel="external"} on the HMRC website.^

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: How much National Insurance you pay

table.body:
Your National Insurance contributions count towards these benefits:

- the basic State Pension 
- the additional State Pension (State Second Pension)
- Jobseeker's Allowance - the 'contribution-based' element
- Employment and Support Allowance - the 'contribution-based' element
- Maternity Allowance
- bereavement benefits - Bereavement Allowance, Bereavement Payment and Widowed Parent's Allowance
- Incapacity Benefit
table.title: What National Insurance is for

table.body:
Your benefits could be affected if there are gaps in your National Insurance record. National Insurance credits help protect them.

You can get credits if you can't pay National Insurance contributions, for example, if:

- you can't work due to illness 
- you're caring for someone

Read more [about National Insurance credits](/boost-state-pension/national-insurance-credits-eligibility "about National Insurance credits") to see if you qualify and how to apply.

^If you're not working or getting credits you can also [top up your National Insurance](/boost-state-pension/voluntary-national-insurance-contributions "top up your National Insurance") with voluntary contributions.^
table.title: Help if you're not working

table.body:
You can check your National Insurance contributions record by contacting HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC). They can also help you get a State Pension forecast. 

The contact details are different depending on where you live:

- [contact HMRC if you're in the UK](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sf=&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=49620&fl0=__dsid:&tx1=2037&raction=view "contact HMRC if you're in the UK"){:rel="external"}
- [contact HMRC if you live or work abroad](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sf=&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=49621&fl0=__dsid:&tx1=2037&raction=view "contact HMRC if you live or work abroad"){:rel="external"}

You can also [calculate your pension credit](/pension-credit-calculator "calculate your pension credit") online.

^You can [apply for a National Insurance refund](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/refunds-complaints/claimback.htm "apply for a National Insurance refund"){:rel="external"} if you think you've overpaid.^

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
